fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If Z is a r.v with standard normal distribution, then X = \mu + \sigma Z is said to have the normal distribution with mean \mu and variance \sigma ^2.
Let X \sim N(\mu , \sigma ^2), the CDF of X is F(x) = \Phi \left (\frac {x - \mu }{\sigma }\right ) where \Phi is the CDF of the standard normal distribution.
The PDF of X is f(x) = \frac {1}{\sigma } \varphi \left (\frac {x - \mu }{\sigma }\right ) where \phi is the PDF of the standard normal distribution.

fr:title.text: Courses › Probability & Statistics for EECS Fall 2024 › Lectures › No. 5: Continuous Random Variables

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Courses › Probability & Statistics for EECS Fall 2024 › Lectures › No. 5: Continuous Random Variables

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An r.v. has a continuous distribution if its CDF is differentiable. We also allow there to be endpoints (or finitely many points) where the CDF is continuous but not differentiable, as long as the CDF is differentiable everywhere else. A continuous random variable is a random variable with a continuous distribution.

Unlike PMF of a discrete r.v., the PDF of a continuous r.v. does not give the probability of a particular value.
P(X = x) = 0 \text { for all } x

For a continuous r.v. X with CDF F_X(x), the probability density function (PDF, 概率密度函数) of X is defined as
f_X(x) = \frac {\mathrm {d}}{\mathrm {d}x} F_X(x)

Similarly, the cumulative distribution function (CDF, 累积分布函数) of X can be obtained by integrating the PDF:
F_X(x) = \int _{-\infty }^x f_X(t) \; \mathrm {d}t

The PDF of a continuous r.v. X must satisfy the following conditions:
Non-negativity: f_X(x) \geq 0 for all x.
Normalization: \int _{-\infty }^\infty f_X(x) \; \mathrm {d}x = 1.
Discrete Case: E(g(X)) = \sum _{x} g(x) P(X = x)
Continuous Case: E(g(X)) = \int _{-\infty }^\infty g(x) f_X(x) \; \mathrm {d}x

A continuous r.v. Z is said to have a standard normal distribution if its PDF \varphi is given by:
\varphi (z) = \frac {1}{\sqrt {2\pi }} e^{-z^2/2}

The standard normal CDF \Phi is given by:
\Phi (z) = \int _{-\infty }^z \varphi (t) dt
Standard normal distribution is denoted by Z \sim N(0, 1). The expectation and variance of a standard normal r.v. are 0 and 1 respectively.
If Z is a r.v with standard normal distribution, then X = \mu + \sigma Z is said to have the normal distribution with mean \mu and variance \sigma ^2.
Let X \sim N(\mu , \sigma ^2), the CDF of X is F(x) = \Phi \left (\frac {x - \mu }{\sigma }\right ) where \Phi is the CDF of the standard normal distribution.
The PDF of X is f(x) = \frac {1}{\sigma } \varphi \left (\frac {x - \mu }{\sigma }\right ) where \phi is the PDF of the standard normal distribution.

Let X_1, X_2, \ldots , X_n be a sequence of i.i.d r.v with finite mean \mu and variance \sigma ^2, the sample mean is defined as \bar {X} = \frac {1}{n} \sum _{i=1}^n X_i Then, as n \to \infty ,
\sqrt {n} \left ( \frac {\bar {X} - \mu }{\sigma ^2} \right ) \to N(0, 1)

The Moment Generating Function (MGF) of a random variable X is defined as
M(t) = E(e^{tX})

fr:title.text: Moments via Derivatives of the MGF

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Moments via Derivatives of the MGF

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Given MGF M(t) of a random variable X, the n-th moment of X is given by
E(X^n) = M^{(n)}(0)

fr:title.text: MGF of A Sum of Independent R.V.s

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: MGF of A Sum of Independent R.V.s

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
If r.v. X and Y are independent, then the MGF of their sum is the product of their MGFs.
M_{X+Y}(t) = M_X(t) \cdot M_Y(t)

Let X be a random variable with MGF M_X(t), then the MGF of a X + b is
E(e^{t(a X + b)}) = e^{b t} M_X(a t)

\operatorname {Var}(X) \leq 0 with equality if and only if P(X = a) = 1 for some constant a

The Moment Generating Function (MGF) of a random variable X is defined as
M(t) = E(e^{tX})

The joint cumulative distribution function (CDF) of two random variables X and Y is defined as
F_{X, Y}(x, y) = P(X \leq x, Y \leq y)
This can be extended to multiple random variables.

The Joint PMF of two discrete random variables X and X is defined as
p_{X,Y}(x,y) = \Pr (X = x, Y = y)
Joint PMF of multiple random variables can be defined similarly.

For discrete r.v. X and Y, the marginal PMF of X is
P(X = x) = \sum _y P(X = x, Y = y)

For discrete r.v. X and Y, the conditional PMF of X given Y = y is
P_{X \mid Y}(x \mid y) = P(X = x \mid Y = y) = \frac {P(X = x, Y = y)}{P(Y = y)}
Discrete r.v. X and Y are independent if F_{X, Y}(x, y) = F_X(x) F_Y(y) and it is also equivalent to the condition: P(Y = y \mid X = x) = P(Y = y) for all y and x s.t. P(X = x) > 0.

If X \sim \operatorname {Pois}(\lambda p) and Y \sim \operatorname {Pois}(\lambda (1 - p)) are independent, then X + Y \sim \operatorname {Pois}(\lambda ) and X \mid (X + Y = n) \sim \operatorname {Bin}(n, p).

If N \sim \operatorname {Pois}(\lambda ) and X \mid N = n \sim \operatorname {Bin}(n, p), then X \sim \operatorname {Pois}(\lambda p), Y = N - X \sim \operatorname {Pois}(\lambda (1 - p)), and X and Y are independent.

If X and Y are continuous with joint CDF F_{X, Y}, then the joint PDF of X and Y is
f_{X, Y}(x, y) = \frac {\partial ^2 F_{X, Y}}{\partial x \partial y}

For continuous random variables X and Y, the marginal probability density function of X is
f_X(x) = \int _{-\infty }^\infty f_{X, Y}(x, y) \; \mathrm {d}y

For continuous random variables X and Y, the conditional probability density function of X given Y = y is
f_{X \mid Y}(x \mid y) = \frac {f_{X, Y}(x, y)}{f_Y(y)}

Continuous random variables X and Y are independent if:
f_{X, Y}(x, y) = f_X(x) f_Y(y)
It is also equivalent to:
f_{X \mid Y}(x \mid y) = f_X(x) \quad \text {and} \quad f_{Y \mid X}(y \mid x) = f_Y(y)

Let X and Y be two random variables, g: \mathbb {R}^2 \mapsto \mathbb {R}, then:
E[g(X, Y)] = \int _{-\infty }^{+\infty } \int _{-\infty }^{+\infty } g(x, y) f_{X, Y}(x, y) \, \mathrm {d}x \, \mathrm {d}y

The covariance of two random variables X and Y is defined as
\operatorname {Cov} (X, Y) = E ((X - E(X)) (Y - E(Y))) = E(XY) - E(X) E(Y)

The correlation between two random variables X and Y is
\operatorname {Corr} (X, Y) = \frac {\operatorname {Cov} (X, Y)}{\sqrt {\operatorname {Var} (X) \operatorname {Var} (Y)}}

For any two random variables X and Y:
-1 \leq \operatorname {Corr} (X, Y) \leq 1
If X and Y are independent, then \operatorname {Corr} (X, Y) = 0.

The Cauchy-Schwarz inequality states that for all vectors \boldsymbol {a} and \boldsymbol {b} in a inner product space, the following inequality holds:
\left | \langle \boldsymbol {a}, \boldsymbol {b} \rangle \right |^2 \leq \langle \boldsymbol {a}, \boldsymbol {a} \rangle \cdot \langle \boldsymbol {b}, \boldsymbol {b} \rangle
where \langle \cdot , \cdot \rangle is the inner product.

In probability theory, we define an inner product between two random variables X and Y as
\langle X, Y \rangle = E (X Y)
the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality states that
|E(XY)| \leq \sqrt {E(X^2) E(Y^2)}

For any r.v. X and constant a > 0, we have
P(|X| \geq a) \leq \frac {E|X|}{a}

Let X be a r.v. with finite mean \mu and finite variance \sigma ^2. Then for any constant a > 0, we have
P(|X - \mu | \geq a) \leq \frac {\sigma ^2}{a^2}

For any r.v. X and constants a, t > 0, we have
P(X \geq a) \leq \frac {E(e^{tX})}{e^{ta}}

Let the r.v. s X_1, X_2, \dots , X_n be i.i.d. with \E (X_i) = \mu and a \leq X_i \leq b. Then, for any \epsilon > 0,
P \left ( \left | \frac {1}{n} \sum _{i=1}^n X_i - \mu \right | \geq \epsilon \right ) \leq 2 \exp \left ( - \frac {2n \epsilon ^2}{(b-a)^2} \right )

Let X_1, X_2, \dots , X_n be a partition of the sample space, s.t. P(X_i) > 0 for all i. Then for any random variable Y on this sample space:
E(Y) = \sum _{i=1}^n E(Y \mid X_i)P(X_i)

Let X, Y be two random variables. Then the conditional expectation of Y given X is a function of X, denoted by E(Y \mid X), defined as:
E(Y \mid X) = \sum _y y P(Y = y \mid X)
E(Y \mid X) = \int _{-\infty }^{+\infty } y f_{Y \mid X}(y \mid x) \, dy

For any random variables X, Y:
E ( E(Y \mid X) ) = E(Y)

The conditional variance of a r.v. Y given X is defined as
\operatorname {Var} (Y \mid X) = E \left ( (Y - E(Y \mid X))^2 \mid X \right )
this is equivalent to:
\operatorname {Var} (Y \mid X) = E(Y^2 \mid X) - E^2(Y \mid X)

For any two r.v. X and Y, we have
\operatorname {Var}(Y) = E(\operatorname {Var}(Y \mid X)) + \operatorname {Var}(E(Y \mid X))

c(X, \hat {X}) = |X - \hat {X}|^2

State s of a Markov chain is recurrent if starting from s, the chain will return to s with probability 1.
State s of a Markov chain is transient if this state is not a recurrent state.
A Markov chain with transition matrix Q is irreducible if for any two states i and j, it is possible to go from i to j in a finite number of steps (with positive probability).
That is, for any states i, j there is some positive integer n such that the (i, j) entry of Q^n is positive.
A Markov chain that is not irreducible is called reducible.

fr:title.text: Period of a State in Markov Chain

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Period of a State in Markov Chain

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
For a Markov chain with transition matrix Q, the period of a state i is the greatest common divisor of all integers n such that the (i, i) entry of Q^n is positive.
d(i) = \gcd \{ n \in \mathbb {N} \mid (Q^n)_{i, i} > 0 \}
If d(i) = 1, then the state i is aperiodic, otherwise it is periodic.
A Markov chain is periodic if it is irreducible and all states have period greater than 1.
A Markov chain is aperiodic if it is irreducible and all states have period 1.

fr:title.text: Stationary Distribution of a Markov Chain

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Stationary Distribution of a Markov Chain

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
A stationary distribution of a Markov chain is a probability distribution \boldsymbol {s} = (s_1, s_2, \dots , s_n) such that
\sum _{i} s_i q_{i, j} = s_j
or equivalently
\boldsymbol {s} Q = \boldsymbol {s}
where Q is the transition matrix of the Markov chain.

A Markov chain is reversible if there exists a probability distribution \boldsymbol {\s } = (s_1, s_2, \dots , s_n) such that
s_i > 0, \sum _{i} s_i = 1
and
s_i q_{i, j} = s_j q_{j, i}
for all i, j, where Q is the transition matrix of the Markov chain.
